The background indicates that China has already experienced three consecutive months of deflation (February, March, April 2025). Such trends, rooted in deep structural issues like a prolonged property sector downturn and weak consumer confidence, do not typically reverse sharply in a single month. These factors create a persistent drag on domestic demand, which is the primary driver of the current deflationary pressure. While the Chinese government is actively implementing counter-cyclical policies to stimulate the economy, the impact of such measures on broad price indices like the CPI often involves a time lag. It is plausible that any stimulus introduced in recent months has not yet fully filtered through to consumer spending by May.

My probability is not higher because the Chinese government has a strong mandate to prevent a deflationary spiral and possesses a wide array of policy tools. There is a non-trivial chance that recently enacted stimulus, a policy surprise, or a favorable base effect from May 2024 could be sufficient to push the year-over-year CPI into neutral or positive territory.

My probability is not lower because the underlying causes of the deflationary pressure are severe and not easily resolved. The combination of industrial overcapacity, the wealth effect from the housing crisis, and cautious household saving behavior creates a difficult environment for generating inflation. The evidence from the preceding three months provides a strong signal that these deflationary forces currently have the upper hand.

I would update my forecast higher (towards Yes) if high-frequency data for May (e.g., retail sales, PMI) were to come in significantly below expectations. I would update lower (towards No) on news of a major, direct consumer stimulus package (e.g., direct cash handouts) or a sharp, unexpected rise in global energy prices.
